RT @TheDemocrats RT if you agree: It‚Äôs time for congressional Republicans to stand up to Trump and say enough is enough. The only way to protect America from our adversaries is to put country over party. We call on the GOP to stand up for our country and hold this reckless president accountable.

We libertarians need to be smarter and more effective in our approach. Acting like partisans‚Äîpushing demagoguery and tribalism‚Äîis a self-defeating proposition. Stand strong on your principles; you‚Äôll find most Americans standing with you.

Worse yet, thanks to the press conference, we‚Äôre likely to see more ineffectual sanctions bills and resolutions of condemnation against Russia, which will serve primarily to stunt further efforts at diplomacy and dialogue.

The widespread reaction on Capitol Hill, for example, has been to rally around the intelligence community. People are proposing resolutions of support for the FBI, despite its dubious track record and unconstitutional activities, particularly with respect to the #4thAmendment.
Nor are libertarian values advanced when the effect of the president‚Äôs press conference‚Äîset aside the intent‚Äîis to further isolate our country from Russia.
People then connect our principles to the president‚Äôs failings, which have nothing to do with libertarianism.

The general public are not more likely to see themselves as libertarian when, for the sake of ‚Äúowning the necons,‚Äù prominent figures associated with libertarianism conflate libertarian-style governance and Trump-style governance.

When a libertarian‚Äôs political prime directive becomes ‚Äúowning the neocons‚Äù (or ‚Äúowning the libs‚Äù) rather than advancing libertarian ideals, then that person undermines libertarianism as a philosophy.

The virtue being signaled is opposition to all things ‚Äúneocon.‚Äù If someone doesn‚Äôt like how the meeting transpired, it must be because that person is a Deep State anti-Trump neocon warmonger, etc.
To suggest that anyone critical of the president‚Äôs conduct opposes diplomacy is to employ a strawman argument. It‚Äôs virtue signaling, not libertarianism.

Even the president ultimately recognized that the press conference did not go well, as he tried to correct his remarks that exonerated Russia. Oddly, it took him more than a day to do so. One wonders why the White House didn‚Äôt act more quickly if it were simply a misstatement.

Perhaps it was just the president showing insecurity, once again, over the legitimacy of his election. Perhaps it was a sign of a more troubling entanglement with Putin. Whatever the case, the press conference was counterproductive to the goal of improving relations.

The impression it left on me, a strong supporter of the meeting, is that ‚Äúsomething is not right here.‚Äù The president went out of his way to appear subordinate. He spoke more like the head of a vassal state.

I suspect that many of the people defending the press conference performance did not watch it in its entirety‚Äîor at all. If they had, they would know that it didn‚Äôt achieve the desired effect of bringing America and Russia closer; in fact, it did just the opposite.

Yet, that‚Äôs precisely the false conclusion some are making. I‚Äôve heard it said that anyone who disapproves of what took place at the press conference is pro-war or anti-Trump. No, some of us are just concerned about the bizarre behavior of our president at a press conference.
We must not, however, fall for the logical fallacy that because diplomacy and dialogue are good, @POTUS‚Äôs performance at the press conference was good.
I believe that this aspect of libertarianism‚Äîthe desire to seek friendship and peace whenever possible‚Äîis among its most appealing qualities.

For my part, I have urged presidents to meet with the leaders of Russia, North Korea, Cuba, and other countries to build better relationships. These interactions make it possible to change behavior, to turn foes into friends.
We say diplomacy and dialogue are good. Few Americans would disagree with that. Peace and prosperity can‚Äôt be secured without communication and engagement.
